args: Put this article into one of the following categories. Use the most specific category that makes sense. If you are unsure, respond Other. The allowed categories are: Abortion, AI, Associated Press, Birthright citizenship, CFPB, Climate, Crypto, D.C., Debt ceiling, DEI in schools, DEI in the federal government, Department of Education, Deportations, DOGE, End birthright citizenship, Eric Adams case, Expanding executive power, Federal funding, Federal grant pause, Federal office space, Federal worker buyout, Federal workers return to office, Federal workforce reductions, FEMA, Firing government watchdogs, Food safety, Foreign aid, Foreign policy, Gaza, Government shutdown, Guantánamo Bay, Health agencies' communications pause, Health care, Immigration policy, Interest rates, Iran, Islamic State, Israel, Jan. 6, Kennedy Center, NIH, NYC congestion toll, Other, Panama Canal, Pardons, Reclassifying federal jobs, Sanctions, Senior government officials ousted, Taiwan, Targeting political enemies, Targeting protesters, Tariffs, The media, TikTok ban, Transgender policy, U.S.-Mexico border, USAID, USPS, War in Ukraine, World Health Organization Respond ONLY with the category. State attorneys general say they will sue to block pause on federal grants At least 20 states have been frozen out of their Medicaid reimbursement systems after the Trump administration ordered a pause in federal grant spending, attorneys general said Tuesday. The attorneys general said they would file a lawsuit to block the federal grant directive, which they said has already led to frozen funds for programs including Medicaid, Head Start in Michigan and child development block grants in Maryland. “We will not stand for any illegal policy that puts essential services for millions of Americans at risk,” New York Attorney General Letitia James (D) said at a news conference also attended by her Democratic peers from several other states. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt, however, said on social media that the Medicaid website portal had suffered an outage, but that Medicaid payments had not been affected and the portal would be “back online shortly.”
